title.narrative: SAM treatment and IYCF for Children U5 and PLW 2017

description.narrative: Action Against Hunger’s rapid SMART survey performed in August in Monguno Town indicated that the GAM rate was 27% while mass MUAC screenings performed by MSF in three IDP camps in MMC and Jere revealed GAM rates between 37.3% to 59.9%. In Yobe, AAH performed mass MUAC screenings in Nangere and Tarmuwa in July 2016 and in Gujba LGA in September where GAM levels were 7%, 25%, and 22% respectively. The findings of the AAH mass MUAC screening in Nangere were in the “Poor” threshold according to the WHO classification using GAM rates, while the GAM levels in Tarmuwa, Gujba, and Monguno reflect an “Extreme Critical” situation according to the IPC for acute malnutrition, and are associated with a significantly increased risk of child mortality. Conditions may be worse in areas that remain inaccessible (FEWS NET Nutrition Update, Oct. 2016). ACF aims to improve access to CMAM services for children 6059 months with SAM. Increase IYCF practices in target communities.
